Issues can be reported at: https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/new/choose

title: scikit-learn/test_target_encoder.py at main · scikit-learn/scikit-learn

last_post.content:
Note that Target Encoding is a risky business: to avoid trivially leaking supervised signal into noisy features, it requires a implementing an internal cross-transform routine in its fit_transform(X_train) method which makes it behave differently that calling fit(X_train).transform(X_train) sequentially.

See the following educational non-regression test to see why its important on a minimal synthetic case:

https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/blob/main/sklearn/preprocessing/tests/test_target_encoder.py#L438

title: ENH Adds TargetEncoder by thomasjpfan · Pull Request #25334 · scikit-learn/scikit-learn

last_post.content:
The TargetEncoder PR has been merged into the scikit-learn main branch!

https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/25334

It's a very efficient way to deal with high cardinality categorical variables for supervised machine learning tasks. See the following quick tutorial to compare its performance with one-hot encoding, ordinal encoding and native support of categorical variables in Gradient Boosted Trees:

https://scikit-learn.org/dev/auto_examples/preprocessing/plot_target_encoder.html

It will be part of scikit-learn 1.3.

title: projects/benchmarks/span-labeling-datasets at v3 · explosion/projects

last_post.content:
Happy to announce the release of spaCy 3.5.1!

It introduces 'spancat_singlelabel', support for mypy v1.0, new operators for the dependency matchers, a 'PlainTextCorpusReader', various bug fixes and more!

We recently also added two new resources:

* https://github.com/explosion/projects/tree/v3/benchmarks/span-labeling-datasets bundles various NER & spancat datasets + .spacy convertors

* https://github.com/explosion/projects/tree/v3/benchmarks/ner_embeddings contains all resources to reproduce the results of our "Multi hash embeddings" technical report: https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.09255

Happy weekend!

title: GitHub - grvsmth/jest_test at ecmascript_modules

last_post.content:
Some years ago I created a small repo to demonstrate using #JestJS to create unit tests for #javascript. Today I'm releasing a new branch to demonstrate how to implement Jest's new native support for ECMAScript modules!

The key steps are:
1. Import jest explicitly
2. Use jest.unstable_mockModule()
3. Inside the `describe` function, use a dynamic import, e.g. `const utilModule = import("../util.js")`
4. Inside the `test` function, extract the class/method
5. Mock away!

https://github.com/grvsmth/jest_test/tree/ecmascript_modules

title: BUG: inconsistency between prepared and unprepared polygon contains predicate · Issue #740 · libgeos/geos

last_post.content:
GEOS is pretty darn robust, but there's an interesting class of failures that are the root of more than one of the extant issues.

When evaluating predicates (true/false tests on geometry relationships) and full DE9IM relationships, JTS/GEOS will perform noding on the inputs before evaluating the relationship between them.

This results in a sort of "heisenberg uncertainty principle" of geometry predicates. The act of evaluating them changes them slightly.

https://github.com/libgeos/geos/issues/740#issuecomment-1325776721

title: GitHub - dogsheep/apple-notes-to-sqlite: Export Apple Notes to SQLite

last_post.content:
Used this to build a new "apple-notes-to-sqlite" Python tool, which calls out to AppleScript under the hood:

https://github.com/dogsheep/apple-notes-to-sqlite

I recorded detailed notes of my ChatGPT prototype in one of the issues there:

https://github.com/dogsheep/apple-notes-to-sqlite/issues/1
